ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: More vocabulary and some grammar usage.
I greatly improved my Chinese vocabulary beyond just simple words-- I learned idioms and sophisticated phrases. I improved by speaking, listening, dialogue, and presentational skills.
Advanced vocabulary, speaking, reading, and writing skills were developed in this class.
Good practice of intermediate/advanced level listening and speaking in Mandarin and intermediate level reading/writing.

I improved on my Chinese hand-writing skills through this course through essays and tests that we had. Furthermore, through our lively class discussions, I learned a lot about Chinese history and culture that I would have otherwise not known about through simply reading text.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Classroom discussion was very engaging. Learned a lot from both classwork and homework, prepared me well for exams. For the most part class was very organized. Grading was pretty generous so I never had to stress about that.

I like that the class size is kept relatively small. Only criticism is that the custom workbook is missing pinyin (supplemental text that aids in pronunciation) in the later dialogues, because this inhibits our ability to practice speaking the dialogue.
The structure and engagement in this class was well developed. Texts and materials, in terms of interest and content, could be improved.
The course is well-structured and goes off a well-written textbook. Mandarin is a pretty mechanical language and consistent practice from a textbook for improvement is a absolute must.
This was a great course that touched upon all skills of language learning and was very engaging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you're interested in improving your Chinese. You pretty much have to either take this course or 156, so taking which one just depends on your learning style.
Yes! You have to put in effort to practice writing characters to succeed with the weekly quizzes and exams, but the content is interesting.

Absolutely, and I would also recommend going to Wang Laoshi's office hours, because she will read over drafts, but more to chat and learn from an incredible person and gem of an instructor. She studied Chinese literature in Taiwan, has been at Yale for decades, and has such a wealth of knowledge about teaching and the Chinese tradition.
Great courses for advanced Chinese for heritage speakers.

Yeah definitely, I think this was a great class and the community of this class is also great. The instructors force the students to interact and encourage the students to hangout outside of the class. It was one of the few classes where time genuinely flew because I was either learning about Chinese culture or listening to Wang Laoshi's funny ass stories.
Yes! Since this was a heritage class, many of peers come from similar background as me, and we were able to build a very strong and supportive community through this course.
